bestBHT.bht: As Jesus made His way to Jerusalem, the great multitudes that followed Him formed into one mass, moving along with Him. Recognizing the wild and unthinking enthusiasm of the crowds, Jesus deliberately acted to check their blind following. He emphasized the seriousness of discipleship, urging those who desired to follow Him to be willing to part with everything and endure great hardships for His name's sake. With a grave countenance, Jesus delivered this solemn message in order to draw their minds away from their own expectations and towards the true cost of following Him.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The 'great multitudes' were doubtless people going to the passover, who moved along in clusters.
Falling in with our Lord had formed themselves into one mass about Him.
On His final journey to Jerusalem.
Philip Schaff: A continued journeying with Him is meant."
The multitudes were probably from different places."
Various companies on the way to the approaching Passover feast.
Archibald T. Robertson: It is a dramatic act on the part of Jesus, a deliberate effort to check the wild and unthinking enthusiasm of the crowds who followed just to be following.
Note 'many multitudes' (οχλο πολλο) and the imperfect tense συνεπορευοντο, were going along with him.
John Gill: ...if they would be his disciples, they must part with all that was near and dear to them; and prepare to suffer great hardships and difficulties for his name's sake...
...with a grave and stern countenance, looking wistly at them, and in the most solemn manner delivered what is hereafter related.
...to draw off their minds from such views, and that they might not be disappointed, acquaints them...

bhtAttempts.bht: As Jesus made His way to Jerusalem, the great multitudes that followed Him formed into one mass, moving along with Him. Recognizing the wild and unthinking enthusiasm of the crowds, Jesus deliberately acted to check their blind following. He emphasized the seriousness of discipleship, urging those who desired to follow Him to be willing to part with everything and endure great hardships for His name's sake. With a grave countenance, Jesus delivered this solemn message in order to draw their minds away from their own expectations and towards the true cost of following Him.

As Jesus journeyed towards Jerusalem, the great multitudes moving along with Him had formed into one mass. Wanting to temper their unthinking enthusiasm, Jesus deliberately acted to check their blind following. He solemnly emphasized the seriousness of discipleship, demanding complete devotion and a willingness to endure hardships for His name's sake. With a grave countenance, He delivered this message, directing their attention away from their own expectations and towards the true cost of following Him.

As Jesus made His way to Jerusalem, the great multitudes that had formed around Him were full of wild and unthinking enthusiasm. Jesus intentionally acted to check their blind following, seeking to draw their minds away from their own expectations. He solemnly emphasized the serious commitment required for discipleship, emphasizing the need to part with all that is near and dear and endure great hardships for His sake. With a grave countenance, Jesus delivered this solemn message, urging his followers to count the cost and prepare to sacrifice everything in their journey of discipleship.

As Jesus journeyed to Jerusalem, the great multitudes that had formed around Him were driven by unthinking enthusiasm. Jesus deliberately acted to temper their blind following, urging them to consider the seriousness of discipleship. He solemnly emphasized the need to part with everything and endure great hardships for His name's sake. With a grave countenance, Jesus delivered this solemn message, redirecting their attention away from their own expectations and towards the true cost of following Him.

As Jesus made His final journey to Jerusalem, the great multitudes that had gathered around Him were full of wild and unthinking enthusiasm. Jesus, aware of their misguided zeal, deliberately acted to check their blind following. With a grave countenance, He solemnly emphasized the seriousness of discipleship, calling His followers to part with all that was near and dear to them and to be prepared to suffer great hardships for His sake. This dramatic act aimed to draw their minds away from their own expectations and towards the true cost of being His disciple.
